text:
So I got asked
this the other day,

what success was
before I got to HBS.

Graduate college,
get a job, pay rent.
How am I looking here?
And being here has really--

almost because
there's been so much

that I didn't know
I didn't know,

it makes you realize
that there's so much
even more out there past that.

So I'm from Southern
California originally.

I grew up dancing, hiking,
loving, being outdoors.

In undergrad, I found finance
and got involved in investment
management.

So I knew I wanted to work at
the intersection of climate

and finance, but I
really wanted to explore

all the different avenues
where those intersect.

I initially had a summer
internship lined up

at another investment
manager, and it was a role
I had envisioned myself doing.

So I was super excited, and
then this other opportunity

came up, more at like a tech
startup kind of culture space

and thinking through
carbon credit business,

so investing actually in
individual carbon credits.

My initial impulse was to go
to CPD and to be like, hey,
I don't know what to do.
I'm scared.
Please help me.

And I had friends who were like,
oh, like you almost shouldn't.
And I'm like, no.
I think I need help.

Because I wanted to understand
what that process could look

like and how to handle it
gracefully and in a way
that kept the relationship open.

And we were able to talk
through basically my options

and how to approach the
process of talking to each firm

and understanding their goals
and objectives and then mine,

and even just
thinking through how

to frame the emails
and the conversation.

Thinking back to how did I do
that jump from asset manager

to tech firm, it was trust that
even if it doesn't work out,
I'll land on my feet.

Even when my path looks very
different from my friends

or people that I also
really love and respect,

I still feel like I'm
on the right path.

These differences
don't necessarily

mean that somebody is
going the right way

and I might be
going the wrong way.

I'm going the right way for
me, and I feel really good
about that.
And it makes me really excited.

In some ways, going back into
traditional asset management

maybe would have been the easier
path or the more obvious path.

But I think doing the
thing that felt harder

and scarier was also the
thing that was more exciting.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
